patient_information: Age: 4 years Sex: male Location: rural Mozambique Travel history: recent travel to rural Mozambique one week prior Comorbidities: HIV-negative
history_of_present_illness: The child was admitted 5 days earlier with the suspected diagnosis of nephrotic syndrome and was started on furosemide and prednisolone; however, his oedema did not subside. Three weeks earlier he had been treated for pneumonia at a health centre.
physical_exam: {'general_appearance': 'Miserable, refusing to eat and apathetic with a puffy face and pitting oedema on the lower legs', 'skin': "Dry and hyperpigmented; it is peeling off like 'flaky paint'", 'hair': 'Brillte, sparse and fair in colour', 'groin_area': 'Ulcerative skin lesions, most prominently in the groin'}
labs_and_diagnostics: Albumin: 2.2 g/dL (reference range: 3.0–5.2 g/dL) Haemoglobin: 7 g/dL (12–14 g/dL)
management_and_clinical_course: Treatment: Admitted to the high dependency area of the nutrition ward and treated according to WHO guidelines for severe acute malnutrition with meticulously calculated amounts of feeds and close monitoring Outcome: The oedema started to settle. The transition to higher caloric feeds was tolerated well and he could be discharged into the community feeding program at day 15
